Comprised of the 3 provinces of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island (PEI), the Maritimes are a charming place to visit.  The people are extremely friendly and welcoming, the scenery is spectacular, and the food is mouth-watering!
Foods You’ll Find
Raw Oysters
Lobsters & Oysters: The deep, cold Atlantic waters off the coast of Nova Scotia has some of the most fertile lobster producing grounds to be found around the globe. In addition to these succulent crustaceans, Canadians are lucky enough to have fresh oysters to enjoy year round. Watch the facial expressions of diners as they consume these succulent little beauties….you’ll soon see that their reputation as an aphrodisiac is not without basis 😉 Oysters are plentiful on both the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Canada, from the Maritime provinces of New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island, and Nova Scotia on the Atlantic coast, to British Columbia on the Pacific coast.
Wild Blueberries: Canada is the world’s largest producer and exporter of wild blueberries or ‘lowbush’ berries as they are sometimes called. These tasty, tangy berries are grown primarily in Quebec and the Atlantic provinces.
P.E.I. Potatoes: The iron-rich sandy, red soil found on Prince Edward Island, is ideal for growing potatoes….really good…world famous potatoes…like Russet, White, Red and Yellow. Prince Edward Islanders know a little about potato growing…they’ve been hoeing and hilling  potatoes since the late 1700s!
Fiddleheads
Fiddleheads: Found throughout the Maritimes, Ontario, and Quebec in Canada, these spiral shoots of fern are best enjoyed fresh during the spring season but can be frozen and consumed year round.  They are a good source of potassium, antioxidants, and vitamin C, and are low in sodium. The small village of Tide Head in the Canadian province of New Brunswick boasts of being the ‘Fiddlehead Capital of the World’…and since no one disputes this claim, the Fiddlehead Capital of the World they shall remain 🙂
Mussels: The mussels from Prince Edward Island are renowned across North America for their sweet taste and tender consistency. They are cultured in the cool waters surrounding this province by suspending them on ropes into the water in mesh bags.  As they aren’t allowed to drag on the ocean floor, the mussels remain free of grit and sand often associated with this tasty crustacean.
Atlantic Canada
Foods You’ll Find:
Snow Crab
Snow Crab: Also called Queen Crab, this shellfish flourishes in the deep, cold waters on the Newfoundland and Labrador Shelf, Cape Breton Island, and the Gulf of St. Lawrence.  Canada, being the largest producer of snow crab, provides two-thirds of the entire world supply.
And….Canada Wide
Canadian Peameal Bacon: Canadians LOVE their bacon. Whether it’s the regular fatty strips of bacon, the sumptuous leaner ‘Canadian bacon’ (which is first cured in a brine and then smoked), or ‘peameal bacon’ – which is cured in a sweeter brine and then rolled in ground peas or, more commonly now, cornmeal – you’ll have no problem to find one or more of these bacons in any Canadian breakfast joint.
Last but not least…Canada Dry Ginger Ale.  We know, we know…you can get ginger ale anywhere… but it’s not all from Canada Dry. Sip this refreshing beverage straight up or mix it with some Canadian Club premium ‘whiskey’….affectionately known simply as ‘C.C.’…..and you’ll soon realize what all the fuss is about!
Once you’re well-fed and ready for more fun….check back with us for the next article in this series.  We’ll provide ideas for shows, festivals, galleries, Canadian artists and entertainers, and more on the Arts & Entertainment scene happening across Canada.  You’ll be even further convinced to make a trip across the border and take advantage of all Canada has to offer….and at a ‘discounted’ rate due to the value of your US dollar!
Part 3: Canadian Arts and Entertainment
If you’ve been following along with our 5-part Series on traveling to Canada, you now know a little about 5 of Canada’s major cities , and we’ve given you a glimpse into Canadian cuisine and the delectable foods you’ll find all across the country.  Are you still drooling over thoughts of a scrumptious butter tart…..maybe a sweet Nanaimo bar…an order of poutine, or a bucketful of freshly steamed mussels?  If you’re unfamiliar with any of these culinary delights, have a look at our previous article in this series.
In Part 3, we’ll examine the Canadian Arts & Entertainment scene. If you’re thinking, “With all the snow and cold up there, people probably just stay home a lot – probably not much in the way of an arts and entertainment scene” – you would be mistaken….sorely mistaken 🙂
Sure, most of Canada gets cold and snow during the winter….sometimes during the autumn and spring, too :-)….but it also has glorious long, lazy summer days, crisp and colorful autumns, and springs that just make you want to close your eyes and breathe in the fresh spring air with a hint of winter still in its grasp.  Any season is a good time to get your travel gear in order and head north of the border.
The breathtaking scenery throughout the breadth and depth of this beautiful country long has held inspiration for artists, sculptors, artisans and craftsmen, and the resulting works are spectacular. Any city you visit while traveling to Canada will have art galleries, museums, artisan shops displaying talents of local, national, and international artists, live music and live theater – again representing both local and global talent.
Canada also produces amazing talent in the music, TV, and film industries – both in front of the mike/camera and behind the scenes.  From pop stars Celine Dion, Natalie Furtado, Avril Lavigne, Shania Twain, Justin Bieber, and The Weeknd, to TV/film stars Donald Sutherland, Kim Cattrall, ‘the 2 Ryans’ – Reynolds AND Gosling, Rachel McAdams, Neve Campbell, Sandra Oh, Josh Jackson, and Seth Rogen, Canada keeps churning out exceptionally capable stars.  And, maybe there is ‘something in the water’ in Canada that allows it to create phenomenal comedic talent that includes Howie Mandel, Martin Short, Jim Carrey, Andrea Martin, Dan Aykroyd, Mike Myers, Catherine O’Hara, and the late, great John Candy.
From the west to the east to the northern coasts, following is a brief description of what you’ll find in the way of ‘Canadian Arts and Entertainment’ including art galleries, museums, live theater and more.
The West Coast – Arts & Entertainment
Vancouver Art Gallery (VAG) – Vancouver, BC
Plan to spend a couple of hours at the VAG , exploring the permanent collection and the traveling exhibits.  A great way to see what is housed in the gallery, at least the highlights, is to sign up for a complimentary one-hour tour.
Prominently and proudly displayed are the works of one of British Columbia’s most prolific and famous artists, Emily Carr .  Emily Carr was influenced greatly by local indigenous people and that impact is directly reflected in her painting style.
The close ties between Asia and Vancouver offer Vancouver the opportunity to act as a gateway to North America for Asian art. VAG has begun to center its focus on Asian-themed exhibits with emphasis on works from Korea, China, Japan, and India.
Bill Reid Gallery of Northwest Coast Art – Vancouver, BC
Bill Reid was one of Canada’s greatest artists. Well known around the globe for his detailed and compelling sculptures, one of which – “The Spirit of Haida Gwaii” – graces the Canadian Embassy in Washington, DC, Bill Reid was also a master carver, a prolific writer/poet, and a goldsmith.  The beginning of his long, successful artistic career began with designing and producing jewelry. With a Haida mother and European father, Bill Reid became especially fascinated with the art traditions of the indigenous people of the northwest coast of British Columbia and he played an integral role in launching these unique talents to the world.
The Jade Canoe – Bill Reid
Bard on the Beach – Vancouver, BC
Seeing the tents rise at the edge of the water in Vanier Park is a highlight of the summer for many locals and tourists. Every summer, Bard on the Beach selects several Shakespearean plays – some tragedies, some comedies – to perform for audiences from around the globe.  Some are performed in their original settings. Some are given a modern twist and modern costumes and are a blast to watch – Love’s Labour’s Lost done up to include jazz, rum runners and a speakeasy?  Comedy of Errors performed with a steampunk theme – too fun!!  Under the expertise of Founding Artistic Director, Christopher Gaze, the productions are truly professional, the actors expertly trained, the costumes phenomenal.  With a natural background (not a backdrop) of local mountains and the Pacific Ocean out the back of the ‘big’ tent, this event is worth a visit.  You can book tickets online in advance, and should…as many performances sell out immediately!
Vancouver Folk Music Festival – Vancouver, BC
Held at stunning Jericho Beach Park on the shores of the Pacific Ocean, the Vancouver Folk Music Festival has been an integral part of summertime entertainment and fun in Vancouver since 1978. While the moniker remains “folk” music festival, artists from many music genres now perform here – hip hop, pop, blues, beats, and bluegrass, West African rock, ‘a little bit of soul, yeah, a little bit of soul’….oh, and, folk, of course 🙂 Past performers at this weekend festival have included the late, great folk artist Utah Phillips, indie pop singer songwriter Feist, rock singer Aimee, and long time fan favorite, Ani di Franco.  Shop at the Artisan Market, enjoy the local food. There is also a Little Folks Village to entertain the children with arts and crafts, face painting, they even can collaborate to create a song and get to perform it live….how exciting is that?  Little Folks Village doesn’t provide ‘child care’ service, though, so adults must accompany the little ‘folks’.
Folk Festival
For more check out  Hello BC’s site –  Arts, Culture & History and Attractions & Entertainment .
The Prairies – Arts & Entertainment
Craven Country Jamboree – Craven, SK
If you love country music, you’ll love the Craven Country Jamboree !  Located in the beautiful Qu’Appelle Valley, roughly 25 miles northwest of Regina, SK., this small town is transformed into a small city of campers in RVs and tents at Jamboree time!  You can purchase a 3-day pass and get ready to par-tay with thousands of other fans – yee….haw!  Or, get a day pass if hunkering down with a bunch of party animals isn’t your cup of tea 🙂  The Jamboree offers an amazing lineup of talent for the entire weekend with a superstar headliner closing out the show on Sunday night.
Winnipeg Art Gallery (WAG) – Winnipeg, MB
The WAG houses an impressive range of historical, modern, and contemporary Canadian art dating from the early 1800s through to present day.
In the historical Canadian collection you’ll see works from artists such as Paul Kane – an artist/explorer famous for his paintings of First Nations people in Western Canada, Frederick Verner – famous for his landscape and scenery paintings of the Canadian plains, and Mary Riter Hamilton – most noted for her paintings of the French battlefields of World War I, documenting the important role Canada’s military played in the successful outcome of the Great War.
The modern Canadian art display includes many works of national historic significance.
Preeminent among these displays is an extensive collection by one of Canada’s acclaimed artists, Lionel LeMoine (L.L.) FitzGerald – the only artist of the Group of 7 based in the west of Canada. Over 1,000 of his paintings, sculptures and other artistic works are available for viewing.
Drawings, sculpture, and video is interspersed with prints and paintings displayed in the contemporary Canadian art section. There is a strong concentration of artists from the Canadian Prairies, particularly those from the Province of Manitoba.
For more check out   Tourism Saskatchewan and Travel Manitoba .
Ontario – Arts & Entertainment
Thunder Bay Art Gallery – Thunder Bay, ON
The largest public gallery you’ll find between Winnipeg, MB and the Ontario city of Sault Ste. Marie, the Thunder Bay Art Gallery is home to a collection of nearly 2,000 pieces of art, largely Aboriginal. The Gallery strongly supports regional, national, and international artists by hosting a number of exhibitions every year.  Drop by their gift shop for something unique for yourself or as a gift for someone at home.
Stratford Festival – Stratford, ON
As expected….a city named for the Bard’s hometown definitely should offer live theater…and Stratford does 🙂  Four different stages offer up a plethora of theatrical pearls from comedies, family plays, musicals, modern themes….to, of course…Shakespeare.  Plays run from April through the end of December. Check out their website , choose something that appeals to your individual taste, and prepare to be entertained!
Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) – Toronto, ON
Second only to the Cannes Film Festival in the number of films premiering and the stars who attend, TIFF transforms Toronto annually into a prime location for ‘stargazers’ and film junkies.
Royal Ontario Museum (ROM) – Toronto, ON
ROM is the largest museum in Canada and one of the largest throughout North America.  The permanent exhibits and those brought in for extended stays, attract over a million visitors every year!  Well worth a visit to check out the art works and the displays and exhibits on natural history and world culture.
The National Ballet of Canada – Toronto, ON
My feet hurt after watching a ballet troupe spend an entire performance, for the most part, on the tips of their toes – imagine what theirs must feel like!  But how moving it is to see beautiful, lithe, classically trained dancers in tights and tutus performing traditional ballets. Founded in 1951, ROM is not the only ballet company in Canada, but it is the largest troupe and is the only Canadian ballet company to present a full range of traditional classics including The Nutcracker, Romeo & Juliet, Swan Lake and La Sylphide. The National Ballet School is separate from but closely connected with the National Ballet of Canada. Graduates of the School include actor Neve Campbell and prima ballerina, Karen Kain, who currently holds the position of Artistic Director with the Company. If you love ballet, you’ll love watching a performance by the National Ballet of Canada. To learn more about the classics the troupe is currently performing including dates, location, and other information, refer to this web page .
The National Gallery of Canada – Ottawa, ON
This Ottawa landmark is a most striking and unique structure designed by world-renowned architect Moshe Safdie. Opened in 1988, the building itself is a work of art in addition to the exceptional Canadian art collection contained within its walls!  The gallery’s permanent collection consists of over 1,200 works of art. Special exhibits of pieces from museums around the globe are featured on an ongoing basis. The gallery selects collections which best reflect the rich mosaic that is Canada’s heritage and culture.
For more check out Ontario Travel .
La Belle Province (Quebec) – Arts & Entertainment
Montreal Museum of Fine Arts – Montreal, PQ
This art museum has even more visitors each year than the ROM in Toronto (which has more than a million)!  For no admission charge, you can browse through Canadian paintings, drawings and prints in the museum’s permanent collection.  There is a charge for admission to view the major shows which frequently are brought into the museum for a limited time.
The Maritimes – Arts & Entertainment
Confederation Centre of the Arts – Charlottetown, PEI
The Centre is Canada’s official memorial to the country’s founding fathers. There is plenty to see both outside and inside the four buildings comprising the Centre of the Arts. Attend a live show performed in the amphitheatre over the noon hour.  Stroll around the grounds and take in the public works of art displayed.
“The Story of Confederation” located inside the Centre, includes a replica of the Confederation Chamber where, in 1864, members attending the Charlottetown Conference discussed plans to create the country of Canada. Take a walking tour with the Confederation Players, actors portraying men and women of the 1860s, to learn more about how Canada came to be.
The Confederation Centre Art Gallery houses historical artifacts and contemporary art exhibits showcasing Canadian works by Canadian talent.
While visiting the Confederation Centre of the Arts, why not take in some live theater as well.  Maybe you’ll be fortunate enough to be there when Anne of Green Gables – The Musical is being performed.  After all, Prince Edward Island is the home of this famous red-haired fictional character .
A Ceilidh (pronounced kay’-lee) – Halifax, NS
Canadian Maritimers love making music!  They also love to dance, sing, ‘eat, drink, and be merry’ 🙂 The heritage of many people of Nova Scotia has its origin in Scotland and Ireland.  To this day, Haligonians (yes, that’s what folks from Halifax are called 🙂 pay tribute to their Gaelic roots and culture with Ceilidhs.  The Free Dictionary defines a ceilidh as “a social event at which there is Scottish or Irish folk music and singing, traditional dancing and storytelling”.  You can expect to hear musicians playing the fiddle, bagpipes, and other instruments.  As with any ‘social event’, food plays a large role in a ceilidh, too.  Throughout the summer and autumn months, many local restaurants host lunch or evening ceilidhs.  Enjoy the music, chow down on some seafood chowder or a lobster sandwich, down a pint or two…. before long you’ll be up on the dance floor doing an Irish jig….yelling “Kiss me…I’m Irish”  🙂
Canadian Awards Shows – Arts & Entertainment
They may not have the international appeal of the Oscars or the Grammy’s….but for those involved in the Canadian Arts & Entertainment scene, these 2 awards shows are a very big deal!
Canadian Screen Awards
Awards for excellence in Canadian film and TV – in front of the camera and behind the scenes – are presented at a star-studded red carpet gala event . Categories honored include Canadian news, sports, documentary, comedy and drama.
Juno Awards
Celebrating everything in Canadian music, the Juno Awards are televised annually and honor the many talented musicians, performers, and songwriters across the country.
Fun For All
So you see…..across Canada, people don’t just sit at home, even during the winter months 🙂  There is way too much to see and hear in the Canadian arts and entertainment scene – definitely no time for hibernation – they leave that to the grizzly bears!  Whether you prefer art galleries, museums, live theater, live music, the opera, or the ballet, you will find all of these events all across Canada.  Check the tourism web page for the specific Canadian province or territory you wish to visit for a full listing of ‘what’s going on?’
Not only is there lots to ‘see and hear’…there is also plenty to ‘do’ in Canada in any season.  If you’re looking for outdoor adventure, Canada will fit the bill easily!  Our upcoming Part 4 of our 5-part Series on Canada will give you some great ideas for outdoor adventure. Answer that call of the great outdoors, pack up your travel gear, and head to the ‘Great White North’….which actually is white only part of the year 🙂  Amazing adventures await you!
Part 4: Canadian Outdoor Adventure
If you’re traveling to Canada this summer and are looking for outdoor adventure, your activity options are virtually endless.  Things to do outdoors run the gamut between ‘easy like Sunday morning’ and…. ‘Are you crazy?? I’m not doin’ that!’
No matter to which part of Canada your travels take you – the coasts and oceans, the prairies, the mountains – this country is made for outdoor adventure!  Here are some ideas of what you can do on the water, in the mountains, in the valleys, on the trails, and elsewhere.  We’ve added a few that will make even adrenaline junkies sit up and take notice 🙂
Top 5 Canadian Outdoor “Mountain” Adventures Outdoor – ‘Ain’t no mountain high enough’…
Mountain Climbing
Mountain climbing – If you want to get high….up into the mountains, that is :-), or prefer to keep your feet a little closer to terra firma, Canada has mountains of all heights for any level of mountaineering.  Scale the peaks of the Stawamus Chief, lovingly known by locals as simply “The Chief”.  Situated near the town of Squamish about an hour north of Vancouver, this intermediate hike has the reward of spectacular views once you have reached the top.  There are marked trails, ladders, and stairs to assist you with your climb up the nearly 2,000 foot mountain side…but there are also narrow ledges and steep inclines to challenge you.  Before you begin your ascent, be sure to visit beautiful Shannon Falls, which is where you will park your vehicle.  There are 3 peaks to climb, and you can conquer all of them in one day, or choose only the South Peak – it also offers fabulous views of the surrounding mountains and the town of Squamish.
Ziplining – Visit Whistler, B.C. and try the granddaddy of them all – The Sasquatch!  This is the longest zipline in Canada and the US and will have you soaring free as a bird above the forests for over a mile! Or book the Eagle tour to ride five different ziplines – all very long rides and all will have you ‘zipping’ along at a pretty good clip.  One of these ziplines is 2,400 feet in length with a 30-storey descent – that’ll have your heart in your throat in short order!  To book or learn more about these breathtaking rides check out their site .
Hang gliding –  You don’t need to pack your Superman cape in your travel gear to do this, but when you’re high up in the air with nothing but the wind beneath you, you’re going to feel like you really can fly!  Unlike parachuting where you are in an upright position (for the most part), while hang gliding, you’re in a prone position and have an even better view….once you’re brave enough to open your eyes, that is 🙂  Whether you’re visiting British Columbia, Ontario, or Quebec, you’ll find places where you can go hang gliding.  For the province of Quebec, have a look at this webpage and book your exhilarating ‘fly like an eagle’ experience.
Mountain biking – Once again, Whistler, B.C., is the place to go for ‘gnarly’ mountain bike runs.  Bring your own bike and gear or rent it there.  The well marked, well traveled bike routes offer everything for the beginner to expert mountain bikers.   Purchase a lift pass to start your ride up high in the slopes and pedal your way down at your own pace.  On at least a few of your runs, take the time to breathe in the fresh mountain air and soak in the spectacular scenery….unless you’re going so fast that it’s all just a blur!
Hiking –  If you’re looking for amazing hikes, with breathtaking scenery, possible wildlife sightings, and fresh mountain air, you’ll find them in the majestic Canadian Rockies regardless of your skill level. In the province of Alberta, guided hikes and less strenuous walks on trails near the mountain towns of Banff, Lake Louise, Jasper and Canmore offer stunning views and are suitable for the beginner and experienced hiker alike. The parks throughout British Columbia are equally spectacular and offer hiking experiences that you’ll not soon forget. Of course, you can strike out on your own. Be certain to let someone know where you are going and when you plan to return.  An even safer and smarter idea is to hire a certified guide to ensure you’ll get the best out of your experience while keeping safe. Day hikes are offered, also backpacking and camping over for several nights is also an option.  Decide what you want to do and get out for your mountain adventure! For more information check out  this site .
Top 5 Canadian Outdoor “Valley” Adventures – ‘ain’t no valley low enough’…
Horseback Riding
These aren’t all ‘valley’ activities….but that is the next line of the song 🙂  Some of these activities will let you slow the pace down….just a little, where others will put a healthy flush on your cheeks and get your heart racing:
Horseback riding – so many areas across this vast country, are fabulous for horseback riding.  One of these areas, with remarkable trails and scenery, can be found in the foothills of the Canadian Rockies near the city of Calgary in Alberta. Local guest ranches and a number of tour operators can have you ‘saddled up’ and ready to ‘ride off into the sunset’.  The weather in the foothills is unpredictable, so your travel gear should include an all-weather jacket; and, shoes with a solid heel will help keep you mounted.  For more click here .
Camping – Choose any one of the 10 Canadian provinces or 3 territories for excellent camping.  Provincial and national parks all offer camping spots – some are free, but the majority require payment, depending on the facilities available.  You may need to book a campsite in advance to avoid disappointment, as most Canadians do love to get out into nature every chance they get.
Bicycling – This is another activity that is popular in Canada from coast to coast to coast.  Many major Canadian cities now have bike lanes to make your ride safer.  Both Vancouver, B.C. and Toronto, ON have scenic bike paths on the shores of the local waters.  In Vancouver, there is an extensive network of bike paths along the Pacific Ocean, False Creek, and throughout the city by which you can access many of the popular tourist spots and more!
Swimming – If you enjoy ‘swimming with the fishes’, Canada will ‘make you an offer you can’t refuse’ 🙂  The rivers and oceans tend to be on the cool side no matter what time of year you visit, but brave souls do venture out into the Pacific Ocean and many of the sparkling rivers – mostly during the lazy, hazy days of summer.  If you prefer to do your swimming in less rugged waters, there are plenty of outdoor and indoor pools as well…but where is the adventure in that? 🙂
Whale-watching – Whether you choose to travel to the west coast of Canada or to the East coast, plan a whale-watching excursion as part of your vacation itinerary.
The best place on the west coast to book a whale-watching excursion is from Vancouver Island. It has some of the best whale-watching opportunities in the world!  If you are fortunate enough to see a pod of orcas cavorting over the waves, or a mammoth humpback breach the surface of the Pacific Ocean, you will be (as the Brits say) “gobsmacked”!  There is plenty of other marine life to keep watch for as well – dolphins, seals, sea lions.  A truly unforgettable experience! For more check out  Tourism Vancouver .
On Canada’s east coast, the province of Nova Scotia has great whale-watching opportunities, particularly during the months of July through the middle of October.  The Digby Neck area of the Bay of Fundy provides the whales with a smorgasbord during the summer… and what whale doesn’t like to eat??  The coastal area along Cabot Trail in Cape Breton is another great location to hop aboard a whale-watching vessel. In addition to whales, you may get to see other marine life –  seals, porpoises, and various seabirds. For more click here .
Top 5 Canadian Outdoor “River” Adventures – ‘Ain’t no river wide enough’…
Fly Fishing
Fly fishing – “Give a man a fish and he will eat for a day.  Teach him how to fish and he will sit in a boat and drink beer all day.” Who ever said this isn’t owning up to it …but there’s a lot of truth in it 🙂  So many parts of Canada offer fabulous fishing.  If fly fishing is what ‘floats your boat’, head up to the Yukon for some of the very best fly fishing you’ll find in Canada, or anywhere really.   What’s your fancy? Trout, pike, whitefish?  The Yukon has those and many other species of fish in rich supply.  For the better part of the year, the climate tends to be on the cool side (downright cold in winter!), which makes for cold lakes and rivers and very tasty fish.  During the months of June, July, and August there is nearly 24 hours of sunlight every day – plenty of time to fish whenever you jolly well please 🙂
Salmon fishing – in British Columbia, you can fish year round, with June through September being the best time for salmon fishing. The rivers throughout the province,  plus the Pacific Ocean are home to 5 species of Pacific salmon – Coho, Chinook, Chum, Pink, and Sockeye.  Their outward appearance doesn’t vary too much, but the flesh color varies from species to species,.  There are several major rivers flowing through British Columbia to the Pacific Ocean, including those closest to the Vancouver area, the Capilano River and the Fraser River.   The Strait of Georgia, the body of water which separates the Gulf Islands and southern Vancouver Island from Vancouver and the mainland of Canada, is a feeding ground for much of the salmon population.  If you have a ‘lucky’ fishing rod, add it to your travel gear….or one will be provided for you if you wish to book a charter fishing trip.
Surfing – ‘Ride, ride, ride the wild surf’….in Canada? Really?  Oh, yes… Tofino, B.C. is Canada’s surf capital, and you can surf here year round! Actually, winter surfing is the best here as that is when the ‘surf’s up’ at its strongest. Whether you’re a surfing virgin, or an experienced ‘surfer dude’, there are waves to catch for everyone in the 22 plus miles of rolling waves and sandy beaches.  The water is cool, so a wetsuit is an  essential piece of travel gear, along with surf-quality boots, gloves, and hood.  If you’re dry and cosy, you’ll be able to catch and ride the waves for longer and, more safely.  Hang ten!
Another amazing adventure can be yours at Skookumchuck Narrows on British Columbia’s spectacular ‘Sunshine Coast’.  This unique sport is called SUP Surfing – where you use a stand up paddleboard or a kayak to ride through this wave explained as follows.  “A massive tidal exchange through the narrows between Sechelt and Jervis inlets puts on an impressive daily show, creating the famous Sechelt Rapids and attracting both nature-lovers as well as extreme sports enthusiasts. As 750 billion litres of seawater rushes through Skookumchuck Narrows at speeds up to 17 knots, the force creates a standing wave that can reach two metres in height.” You’ll want to check out this amazing video illustrating just what you can expect from this incredible adventure!
Stand Up Paddleboard Skookumchuck: Greatest ride of my life! from luke hopkins on Vimeo .
Kayaking/canoeing – The province of Ontario offers incredible kayak or canoe opportunities. The landscape through which you can paddle is breathtaking!  Ontario Parks operates over 7,500 interior campsites – many of which you can get to only by canoe or kayak. You can rent canoes and camping equipment at many of the provincial parks.  Local outfitters provide guided trips or can help you plan your own trip.  Check out the Ontario Parks web page at http://ontarioparks.com/en.  Be prepared, follow the rules regarding campfires, wildlife, etc., know the limits of your own abilities, and have a wonderful time!
White water rafting – This one’s for you, Adrenaline Junkies 🙂   Here’s a package that is sure to set your ticker racing!  It combines two of the most thrilling adventures in the Rockies! Start by white water rafting the mighty rapids of the Kicking Horse River…. then experience the exhilaration of jumping from a perfectly good plane at 10,000 ft!   https://www.banffadventures.com/
5 Bonus Canadian Outdoor Adventures – with a twist
Kayaking
Looking for something a little unique?  Try thinking outside the box with these activities:
Flying trapeze class – okay, so this technically isn’t an ‘outdoor’ activity….but a unique one nonetheless!  If you’ve ever had the desire to ‘fly through the air with the greatest of ease’, the Toronto School of Circus Arts offers drop-in classes for you to take!  Defy gravity and challenge your body to reach new heights. It’ll make your next night out way more fun….and safer. When you decide to ‘swing from the chandelier’…you’ll look like a pro 😉
Dogsledding and/or Swim & Kayak with Beluga Whales – these are two other incredible outdoor adventures in the province of Manitoba which you can do even in summer. A visit to the northern town of Churchill is most often done during the winter when both dogsledding and tours to spot polar bears are extremely popular.  If you visit Churchill during the warmer months however, you still can experience the thrill of dogsledding – a cart with wheels replaces the sled – et voila….you’re a ‘musher’!
Or what would you say to a swim with or kayak among beluga whales during the summer months?  That would be an amazing experience, right?  You can do both here in the Hudson Bay and Churchill River.  Be on the lookout for other wildlife, too.  Caribou and moose, wolves and foxes all call this area home.  You might even be lucky enough to see some polar bears if you know where to look.  During summer months they can still be spotted out on the tundra or along the rocky coastline.
Cable wakeboarding –  Here’s another one for you adrenaline junkies!  Unlike wakeboarding behind a motorboat, in ‘cable’ wakeboarding you are pulled by…well, by a ‘cable’ system. Every extreme trick you can perform while wakeboarding behind a boat, you can do while cable wakeboarding.  A great facility is located in Winnipeg, Manitoba.  Here you’ll find two lakes, one smaller one for beginners to learn the basics of this sport; and a much larger lake where you can hone your tricks, even ‘get air’ if you’re experienced enough.  Learn more about this or book your own thrilling adventure at   Adrenaline Adventures .
Cliff climbing –  Rock climbers from around the world travel to the beautiful Okanagan Valley of British Columbia to tackle the Skaha Bluffs just outside of the city of Penticton. Cliffs range up to 250 feet in height, offering challenges that are suitable for both beginning and advanced climbers.  If cliff climbing is a bit above your pay grade :-), you’ll also find plenty of hiking trails to get you to the top.  The spectacular views of Skaha Lake, the city of Penticton, and a large portion of the Okanagan Valley are well worth the climb.
Zip lines plus – If you want to add a little ‘zip’ to your zip lining experience, you’ll love this adventure!  “The Treetop Adventure Full Course features 70 different obstacles from rope swings to balance beams that reach heights of up to 60 feet above the forest floor. Rise to the challenge and experience the canopy from an elevated perspective.”  Adventure, fabulous scenery, fresh air, and fun all rolled into one awesome experience!  Check them out at Super Fly Ziplines .
5 Packing Tips for Summertime Canadian Outdoor Adventures:
Outdoor Gear
If your summer activities will include dog sledding and/or swimming with belugas in Churchill, Manitoba – the weather can be on the cool side. Summer temperatures average only between 40 F and 60 F.   Of course, it can get warmer or cooler so best to include these items with your travel gear: a waterproof jacket, hat, sunglasses, hiking boots, shorts, pants, sunscreen, and insect repellent.
The weather in the Canadian Rockies can be very unpredictable. Pack clothes that you can layer and you’ll be prepared for whatever Mother Nature throws at you! The sun is strong – sunglasses and a hat will protect you from UV rays – and should be worn no matter what time of year you visit.  In summer, July through September, Rocky Mountain destinations enjoy warm weather… but that can change at the drop of a hat. Be sure to pack a rain/wind proof jacket and a warm sweater.
To keep safe your personal and financial information, your travel gear always should include an RFID-blocking wallet or neck-stash whenever you travel.
If you plan to surf in Tofino, B.C., a wetsuit is essential, along with boots recommended for surfing, gloves and a hood so you’ll be able to get the most out of your surf time.
White water rafting?  Your travel gear should include a towel and a swimsuit.  DON’T bring a camera (waterproof is okay), expensive jewelry, or other valuables.  Leave those items in your hotel safe or in another secure location.
Like the song says, “Ain’t no mountain high enough, ain’t no valley low enough, ain’t no river wide enough….to keep you from gettin’ to…Canada this summer…to experience and enjoy any and all types of outdoor adventure!
Throughout the previous 4 parts in this 5-part Series, we’ve introduced you to 5 of Canada’s top cities , given you some ideas on what constitutes ‘ Canadian cuisine ’ and where to find it, a peek into Canada’s arts and entertainment scene , and now, where to find outdoor adventure.
Don’t miss the final article in this 5-part Series coming soon. We’ll give you a taste of train travel across Canada, and will answer questions for you such as:  Where can I travel by train in Canada?  What amenities can I expect on a train?  Are train stations easy to get to?  What about the cost?  Come back shortly to check it out!
Part 5: Traveling By Train in Canada
Ahh….the romance of traveling the rails – the soothing sway of the train, the clickety-clack of steel on steel as the wheels cross the rails carrying you to a new destination…a new adventure, and the best part – the view!  Train travel across Canada allows you to see some of the world’s most spectacular scenery – the majestic Canadian Rockies, sparkling emerald green and steel blue lakes and rivers, the green or golden wheatfields of the prairies, rugged windswept beaches and more.
Wheat Field
From the moment the conductor shouts, “All aboard!” (do they still do that? 🙂 ) and you step on board, train travel in Canada means it’s time for you to relax.  Settle into your roomy, reclining coach seat and do whatever you jolly well please: read a book, chat with other passengers, have a snack or a full meal, enjoy a refreshing beverage, take some pictures…or a nap, or just sit back and inhale the incredible views…your options are endless.
Choices of Train Travel in Canada:
VIA Rail
VIA Rail is the national rail system of Canada providing 19 routes across the country. Select from 3 types of coaches – Business Class, Economy Class and Touring Class. Fares vary according to distance traveled, region of travel, length of journey, and class of service.  You qualify for a fare discount if you are a senior (65+), youth, student, or part of a group traveling together. The purchase of a CANRAILPASS is a more economical way for you to take seven trips in Economy Class within a specified period of time.
Formal Dinner
Meal service on VIA Rail trains is in either dining cars or lounge cars.  In the dining car, you’ll be offered formal dining service, often with a five-course meal at dinner time, and a complete menu.  The lounge car provides both snack and meal service. Some trains offer ‘seat service’ where the food is delivered to you at your seat.  You can pop into the bar to enjoy a tall cool one and meet new people.
If your passenger train includes a Dome Car, be sure to spend time in the upper level observation dome lounge and take in the panoramic views.  When you’ve had your fill of the amazing scenery, head to the dome car’s lower level for a leisurely cocktail at the bar or for a meal in the dining area.
Tip:  Purchase your ticket in advance of your trip to guarantee a seat on the train you want to take.
Amtrak & VIA Rail Combined
Passenger trains operated by the American company Amtrak , connect with Canada’s VIA Rail for travel between these Canadian and US destinations:
From Montreal Central Station:  the Adirondack train travels between Montreal, QC, Canada and Albany and New York City, NY in the USA.
From Toronto Union Station: the Maple Leaf train travels between Toronto, Aldershot, and Niagara Falls, ON in Canada and Buffalo and New York City, NY in the USA.
There is also a connection between Toronto, ON and Chicago, IL (via Buffalo).
From Vancouver Pacific Central Station: the Cascades train travels between Vancouver, BC, Canada, and Seattle, WA, Eugene, OR, and Los Angeles, CA in the USA.
Rocky Mountaineer
Rocky Mountains Kananaskis Country, Alberta
Experience the splendor of the Rockies and the diverse geography of western Canada from the comfort of The Rocky Mountaineer . This passenger train offers exclusive daylight-only rail service between Calgary, Banff, or Jasper, AB and Vancouver, BC on VIA Rail Canada.  Traveling only during daylight hours affords you the best possible opportunity to view the spectacular scenery as you chug along through the Canadian Rockies.
Eastern Canada Rail Tours
Quebec City
Book one of many rail tours available that let you explore popular Canadian destinations within the provinces of Ontario (ON), Quebec (QC), New Brunswick (NB), Nova Scotia (NS), Prince Edward Island (PEI), and Newfoundland/Labrador (NL).  There are plenty of exciting landmarks and areas to visit while you’re enjoying a stop in some of the major Canadian cities including:
Toronto, ON – Take the elevator to the top of the CN Tower for fabulous 360-degree views of the city.
Niagara Falls, ON – These world famous thunderous falls are a must-see.
Ottawa, ON – See the Parliament Buildings in Canada’s national capital, shop in trendy  Byward Market, walk along the Rideau Canal.
Montreal, QC – Experience the old world charm of Montreal. Browse the chic boutiques and other shops. Stroll through historic Old Montreal for excellent shopping, dining, and sightseeing.
Quebec City, QC – Walk along the cobblestone streets and browse in the wonderful little shops you’ll pass.
Moncton, NB – If your train stop in Moncton is long enough…rent a car and drive to Magnetic Hill.  Drive down the hill, put the car in neutral, and experience the strangeness of having the car roll back up the hill…cue the music from the ‘X Files’ here, folks 🙂  Now that would be pretty weird!!
Halifax, NS – Your train travels can take you to this port city  or to the nearby major tourist attraction, Peggy’s Cove.
Cavendish, PEI – In the picturesque province of Prince Edward Island, visit the location that inspired the famous book, Anne of Green Gables, penned by Lucy Maud Montgomery.  Although the novel was first published over a hundred years ago, the character of Anne Shirley still draws thousands of tourists to the region each year.
A train trip through Eastern Canada would be an incredible journey with memories to last a lifetime.  There are several companies from which you can Book one of many rail tours .
Royal Canadian Pacific
If you’re looking for something extremely luxurious and out of the ordinary, book a private charter luxury rail tour with Royal Canadian Pacific . Choose from among some extraordinary vacation adventures including: a private golf tour or a fly-fishing adventure. Get your golfing buddies together for incredible rounds of golf at some of the best courses in Western Canada, or gather up friends and family for some of the best fly-fishing you will find.
Not only are the activities amazing off the train, the train itself and the service you’ll receive are first-class all the way!  Enjoy your own private stateroom, open bar service, and delectable cuisine.  All this, combined with friendly Canadian hospitality, will make this a trip of a lifetime.  For more itineraries or information check out their website .
Luxury Travel
The Pipe Mountain Coaster – Revelstoke, BC
This is not technically a train ride….but you do sit in a cart and ride along a ‘track’.  You can travel up to 26 mph over .87 miles of high speed rail with a vertical drop mixed in just to keep it interesting 🙂  The great thing about this ride is that you control the speed, so if white knuckles aren’t a good look for you….you can lower your speed and enjoy the ride at a much more civilized pace.  Children can ride in the cart with you making this activity a great experience for the entire family.
Benefits of Train Travel
Leisurely pace – if you’re in a rush to get to your destination….train travel definitely is not your best option.  The steady clickety-clack of the wheels will get you where you want to go…but it won’t be speedy!  You won’t find a ‘bullet train’ crossing Canada just yet.
Relaxed and comfortable – Train seating is larger with more legroom than you’ll ever have on a bus or in an airplane. And, unlike bus or air travel, you can in fact ‘move freely about the cabin’ 🙂 and into the next coach…the dining car, lounge car and observation cars.
Wired – Free Wi-Fi and plug-ins for your cell phone and laptop are provided.  Download the VIA Rail mobile app for instant access to your train status, boarding pass and itinerary.
Convenience –  Trains tend to run on time and offer frequent service to accommodate even the most hectic schedule.
Location – Train stations are normally located at or near the business and downtown area of the city.  This can be a major convenience when you consider just how much time you would need to spend transferring between the airport and the city center.
Safety – Statistically speaking, rail travel is the safest way to travel.  If you’re a bit of an ‘aerophobe’ rail travel will get you where you want to go….not quickly, mind you…but at least you’ll be cool, calm and collected at the end of your journey rather than the jittery mess you might be if you had to fly 🙂
Generous baggage allowance – NOT all trains permit checked luggage but the rail line will state your luggage allowance during the booking process, on your confirmation email, and again on  your boarding pass.  If your train is equipped to handle checked baggage, you may check a maximum of 2 x 50 (100 pounds) of personal baggage free of charge with every adult ticket purchased for travel in Canada. Two bags can be taken on board as carry-on luggage – 1 personal item (max weight 25 lbs) and one larger item (max weight 40 lbs).  No single item over 50 pounds will be allowed as carry-on. Many trains that allow checked baggage also can easily carry sports equipment such as skis, kayaks, and golf clubs. Be sure to confirm this at the time of booking your trip as there may be a surcharge for oversize items.
Excellent sightseeing – Riding the rails affords you the opportunity to ‘see the sights’ at ground level rather than peering down through clouds at the tiny figures way down on the ground.  Even a road trip by car isn’t privy to the unique views of the countryside that you’ll see from a train. The wide windows and observation decks provide a unique sightseeing experience.  Rail travel across Canada offers superb views of the country’s natural attractions including the majestic Rocky Mountains.
Comfortable sleeping accommodations – Overnight trains are equipped with deluxe reclining sleeper seats with leg rests, trays and lighting.  Some VIA Rail trains have private suites with access to an on-board shower.
Social opportunities – Take the opportunity to speak with other tourists traveling with you, often from other countries.  The observation and lounge cars are especially good for starting conversations.  You can chat up your ‘neighbors’ in the area of your seat, too….just make sure they want to chat with you before monopolizing their time 🙂
Packing Tips for Train Travel in Canada
big Horn Sheep
When you travel by train you can take on board way more travel gear than either a plane or a bus allows you.  Of course, there are weight restrictions for your train luggage, too (see #7 above) but they are more generous.  And, keep in mind that if you need or want to take a plane for any leg of your travels in Canada…you don’t want to be carrying ‘everything but the kitchen sink’ and end up getting hit with overweight baggage fees if your luggage weighs too much for air travel.
Include in your travel gear a small pillow and blanket if you’ll be traveling overnight and didn’t book a suite.  You can purchase pillows and blankets on board, and they will be provided if you have paid for a suite with a bed; but, since your luggage allowance is not too restrictive, you may as well take some of the comforts of home with you.
You’ll want to get out and get some fresh air at scheduled station stops.  Pack a rain/wind-proof jacket that you can throw on as you disembark.  Some of the stops –  especially through the Canadian Rockies – will be downright brisk!
Binoculars will come in very handy – at your seat, of course…but especially when you’re in the dome car with its panoramic views.  With the help of binoculars, you just might spot some wildlife or birds that you would not otherwise be able to see. And…if you ‘ooh and aww’ enough while you’re using them… you can pick up a couple of bucks by renting them out to other passengers who think they’re missing out on something 😉
Take along a camera to capture some spectacular memories as you roll across this incredibly beautiful and picturesque country.
We hope you have enjoyed your ‘exploration’ of Canada through this 5-Part Series.  If there are other subjects on Canada you would like to have more information about, please let us know – we’ll be happy to add more articles about things to see and do when traveling to Canada.
